data.title: 15 ‚Äì Love & Hisses
data.text:
Jump to comments

I‚Äôm sure you remember Orlando. A year ago, he looked like this:

And now, when he‚Äôs laying in wait for his big sister Pickles to come along, he looks like this:

Isn‚Äôt that an AWESOME picture?

When he‚Äôs trying to ‚Äúrescue‚Äù his new big brother Hobo, he looks like this:

‚ÄúGimme your paw, Hobo! I‚Äôll pull you through!‚Äù

Orlando‚Äôs big brother Hobo looks like this:

And when I saw that picture, I was like ‚ÄúHoly cow! He looks JUST like‚Ä¶‚Äù

Tig, from the Sons litter in 2011. Right down to the patch of black on their chin!

But we knew they weren‚Äôt the same cat, not only because all Challenger‚Äôs House cats are id-chipped before they‚Äôre adopted out (Hobo didn‚Äôt have an id chip), but also because Hobo‚Ä¶

Has a full-length tail.

And Tig just had a nubbin.

Which leads me to the reason I‚Äôm sharing all these great pictures with y‚Äôall. Teresa (Orlando‚Äôs and Pickles‚Äôs and Hobo‚Äôs mama) has a question, and I thought y‚Äôall might be interested in chiming in! Teresa said:

Question regarding Hobo‚Ä¶. our newly rescued adorable, sweetheart of a marshmallow poof. Keeping in mind his background ‚Äì we have seen him outside randomly for 2 years, but more often since the day we chose Orlando, and then non-stop in Dec/Jan. Happily we now have him indoors but with limited access around other animals until a recheck with Vet and ‚Äòall-clear‚Äô. He is 15 pounds of fluff, about 4 yrs old, and was neutered and declawed by whomever his owners were, at some point.‚Äé

My curiosity, I know it‚Äôs a silly question, is this. Have you encountered an adult cat that pretty much looks like they‚Äôre walking on an ice rink when they walk on smooth tile or wood floors? This boy is clumsily adorable now, as I watch him carefully walk across my kitchen floor! He has been in a room that‚Äôs carpeted for the past few weeks, and I‚Äôm now letting him out to explore more of the house, by himself. Could it be no front claws, or his big size, or new-place-nerves, or who knows how long since he‚Äôs actually been inside a house and on tile, or just plain akward‚Ä¶? Have you seen this with any of your backyard rescues?

I told Teresa that I haven‚Äôt seen that before, myself, but I think that maybe it‚Äôs just a matter of new-place nerves and possibly he hasn‚Äôt been on smooth tile or wood floors in a long time. I mean, a carpet is similar to a lawn, in that there‚Äôs some ‚Äúgive‚Äù to it. I‚Äôm sure he‚Äôs been on concrete, but tile and wood are smoother and feel different than concrete. I‚Äôll be interested to hear whether his walk changes as he gets used to it.

I‚Äôd like to hear if any of y‚Äôall have opinions/experience with that sort of thing. Please share!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The other day I took the kittens into the bathroom so that I could clean their room without any additional ‚Äúhelp.‚Äù When I was done and went back into the bathroom, they‚Äôd curled up on the chenille rug in front of the litter box and gone to sleep. I carried them back into their room, and they rallied to play for a few minutes, but it wasn‚Äôt long before the sleepies overtook them again.

‚ÄúAm exhausted, lady.‚Äù

They climbed into my lap.

‚ÄúWhy she keep makin‚Äô us look up? She gettin‚Äô to be annoying.‚Äù

Paul was the first to succumb to the sleepies.

Mary wasn‚Äôt far behind (and would have fallen asleep even sooner if Peter hadn‚Äôt kept biting her).

I made bunny ears with Paul‚Äôs ears, but to be honest, it just isn‚Äôt as much fun if they‚Äôre not outraged by it.

Peter was all ‚ÄúWhy everyone got to go to sleep? I wanna play!‚Äù

He climbed up for a snuggle, and ended up like this.

Then he fell asleep, too. I had to pee, but what was I supposed to do? It‚Äôs illegal to disturb a kitten‚Äôs rest for such a mundane reason, and I‚Äôm pretty sure that disturbing the rest of THREE kittens would have landed me in the hoosegow for sure.

Lucky for me (and my bladder), they really only snoozed for about 15 minutes before waking up to wreak havoc again.

Yesterday, I loaded the kittens up in the carrier and took them for their combo (FeLV & FIV) test. They tested negative, which I fully expected. What I didn‚Äôt expect was how well they handled the whole experience. They were calm and relaxed in the carrier, I didn‚Äôt hear a peep from them all the way to the vet or all the way home.

What I‚Äôm saying is that it appears they‚Äôre excellent travelers. In case that‚Äôs of interest to you. üôÇ

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Only one video today, and it‚Äôs a short (but utterly adorable) one. I was watching Paul and Peter, hoping they‚Äôd run and play, and wasn‚Äôt paying enough attention to Mary. She let me know by spitting at me. When I turned and asked her if she‚Äôd just spit at me, she did it again. The sassy little brat!

YouTube link.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Please note that Sheriff Mama (Kara) is NOT going out there. Warm, muddy weather she can handle. The ice? Not so much. (It was 72 here yesterday. Today, the high is supposed to be 30, and we‚Äôre apparently going to have an ice storm. SIGH.)

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Previously

2014: Ferdinand was the last one to run off, because he‚Äôs NOT SKEERED OF NO STRANGERS.

2013: That‚Äôs right, still bakin‚Äô.

2012: Oh, look! Time to eat. That only happens constantly, we‚Äôre lucky I had the camera with me while it was happening.

2011: No entry.

2010: No entry.

2009: No entry.

2008: Sometimes the wait is so long and strenuous that he sits there, dozing.

2007: Sugarbutt does his Popeye impression.

2006: No entry.

2005: No entry.
